title: AI Career Reflection: A Prompt to Evaluate Professional Adaptability
subtitle: A Slow AI prompt for clearer thinking and grounded reflection.
author: Dr Sam Illingworth
content_html:
Many people sense that their working lives have grown heavier. Expectations accumulate. Timelines contract. The pace quickens in ways that are hard to pinpoint. AI often serves as a convenient explanation for these shifts, typically framed as either a threat or an opportunity for reinvention.

In this post we will

  • Offer a way to notice how you experience change in your working life.

  • Use a prompt that supports reflection rather than forecasting.

  • Invite a conversation about adaptability without pressure.

Conversations about AI and careers frequently move toward speculation. People are asked whether specific roles will survive, whether industries will change shape, or whether tasks will move into different hands. These questions distract from the immediate necessity of staying grounded when the structure around you is moving.

This week’s Slow AI prompt is written with Katharine Gallagher from Learn Grow Monetize. Her work centres on growth during periods of uncertainty and on the practical steps that help people use their skills with confidence. This prompt is designed to help readers notice their current conditions and responses to change.

Effective practice in a changing workplace begins with understanding your own patterns, not accepting other people’s narratives.

Slow AI is a shared space for reflection. Posts are free. Paid subscriptions support the work in exchange for bespoke poetry.

Step-by-step

Try this prompt with your AI tool of choice:

Guide me through a reflective exercise on my relationship with work as AI becomes more present. Help me explore three areas. First, ask me questions that clarify how I experience pressure, pace, and expectation in my current work. Second, help me consider how AI might support me in working with more calm and clarity. Third, help me examine how my working life could shift if I define security through skills, learning, and adaptability rather than job structure. Ask one question at a time. Do not offer explanations or conclusions. Your role is to help me notice my own experience with more precision.

Choose an AI model that does not train on your data. Let the dialogue unfold slowly. Notice how your answers change once the tool invites you to look more closely. You might realise that your concerns relate less to automation and more to identity. You might find that the idea of change feels manageable when you explore it without noise.

If you are new to Slow AI, here is our first invitation.

A moment from Katharine

Initially, I found it tough to choose which AI to go with. With work I use many different AI models but the prompt asked for a model that wouldn’t train on my data, so I finally decided on Claude Opus 4.1 because it offers thoughtful and careful responses and I don’t use it a lot.

To my surprise, the questions flowed naturally and I felt like I was interacting with a caring friend—insightful enough to challenge me, yet respectful enough to let me to work things out on my own. So looking back, I probably ended up sharing more than I thought I would as my trust was gained with the progress we were making.

As the conversation unfolded, my answers sparked questions that really got to the heart of my career choices. The questions were actually open-ended and really got me thinking as every layer was peeled back. There were many moments where I found myself genuinely pausing and reflecting upon the direction I’m headed.

But it didn’t feel like the AI was leading me; I felt like I was in charge of the conversation and I was speaking to an empathetic friend who was invested in my success.

The questions kept coming, drilling down closer to the heart of the problem of what I needed to do to move toward my goals.

Even when I purposely revealed my messy, real-life problems, I was offered perspectives I hadn’t thought of and solutions I actually needed to hear. By the end of the interaction the experience had really helped me gain clarity about my situation in a way I hadn’t managed yet on my own.

What surprised me the most was how this reflection slowed me down in a way I really needed. Most discussions about AI and the future of work feel panicked—filled with speculation about what’s coming, what might disappear, and which roles will survive. This prompt didn’t push me to predict anything; instead, it encouraged me to notice what’s already happening in my work life and how I’m responding to it.

Instead of jumping to worst-case scenarios or trying to fix everything all at once, this prompt gradually revealed how to cope in a changing career landscape. It gave me the space to recognize my own patterns—where I feel stable, where I feel stretched, and allowed me to figure out my next step.

What to do with it

If you want to share:

  • Describe one insight the reflection revealed that you had overlooked.

  • Note where the AI’s questioning helped you stay with your own experience rather than drifting into prediction.

  • Consider how your thinking shifted once the pace of the reflection slowed.

Why this matters

Most writing about AI increases pressure. It invites people to think in terms of disruption, competition, or risk. This can obscure a simpler truth. People have always adapted. They continue to do so now. Focus on what change requires from you.

This prompt eliminates binary thinking. The questions help you understand where your working life feels steady and where it feels stretched. They help you recognise the skills you already possess and the places where learning might open new possibilities.

Used in this way, AI tools can provide clarity on patterns without promising security, by helping to identify which experiences stem from fear or development.

From What AI Takes When You Aren’t Looking

and I were and I were struck by the collective anxiety regarding the atrophy of 'productive struggle’ in the age of AI.

highlighted the specific cognitive trade-off identified by the models themselves. By bypassing the frustration of navigating chaos and filtering sources, users sacrifice the mental resilience and deep retention that only emerge from solving a problem independently. Convenience, in this context, acts as a barrier to long-term memory.

refined this by naming premature convergence as a primary risk for experts. Diminishing tolerance for complex thinking is the primary danger. When AI provides an answer too early, it cuts off the personal metaphors and nuanced insights that only arise under the pressure of not-knowing.

argued that the most significant loss is the practice of distillation. Outsourcing the act of tidying or prioritising information removes the cognitive reps required to turn messy inputs into a clear throughline. Without this internal compression, the user remains an editor of the machine’s logic rather than the architect of their own point of view.

Taken together, these perspectives suggest that the true cost of speed is the quiet erosion of intuition. We arrive at the destination faster, but we no longer understand the terrain.

If you try this week’s prompt, Katharine and I would love to hear what you noticed about your own relationship with work.

We read and respond to all your comments.

Go slow.
